Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Pulsed and Pressed: the Interactive Effects of Disturbance Intensity and Complex Chemical Exposure on the Productivity of Urban Stream Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Streams in urban landscapes can be negatively impacted by increased flooding due to runoff from impervious surfaces and elevated exposures to both nutrients and pollutants that wash off of those surfaces and can be delivered from inadequate waste water treatment systems. Understanding the individual contributions of these different factors in limiting the productivity and health of urban streams is important for an understanding of the impacts of land use changes, but difficult to identify, because they can occur simultaneously. This project will make use of controlled experimental stream channels to separate how physical disturbances associated with high flows and increased contaminant exposure affect the productivity of stream ecosystems. In small streams, almost all of the productivity is associated with organisms living on the stream bed. Stream beds vary in their stability, or susceptibility to disturbance, largely due to the mixture of streambed materials including the sizes of sediments and rocks. The researchers will compare the rates of recovery and compositions of streambed communities in experimental channels following exposure to storm flows. The experimental treatments will involve different doses of common urban contaminants added to the stream water and adjusting the size of sediments within the streambed. The researchers will train a high school student from a rural community in New York in research, develop a lesson plan for high school environmental science students, and engage the public through a research website and professional meetings.

The goal of this research is to experimentally measure the independent and interactive effects of physical (pulse) and chemical (press) disturbance on aquatic ecosystem productivity. The researchers will test the alternative hypotheses that: 1) more severe disturbances may exacerbate the effects of chemical stress by increasing the susceptibility of biofilms to contaminant exposure; or 2) less severe disturbance may exacerbate the effects of chemical stress by increasing the accumulation of contaminants in biofilms. Water chemistry, biofilm composition, and whole-stream metabolism will be measured throughout the recovery period following a physical disturbance in experimental stream channels with cobble beds and sand beds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A wide variety of organic and inorganic contaminants are detectable in streams across the United States, yet we still have a limited understanding of their impacts on stream ecosystem function at environmentally relevant concentrations. In cities, non-point source contamination can reach streams through subsurface leaky sewer pipes and from surface stormwater runoff that carries with it metals, nutrients, and organic contaminants washed from impervious surfaces such as roads, parking lots, and roofs. In addition to delivering contaminants to streams, stormwater flows tend to have elevated hydraulic erosive power on the streambed as a result of the efficient routing of precipitation off of roads and through subsurface stormwater pipes directly into streams. Therefore, the algae and bacteria that create living biofilms, which grow on streambeds and perform many ecosystem services including excess nutrient removal, are more frequently physically disturbed suppressing their productivity. Contaminant effects on whole-stream productivity are almost impossible to isolate in urban streams in the field because they are correlated with the overwhelming influence of physical disturbances.

 

The main research objective of this project was to use controlled experimental stream channels to disentangle how physical disturbance and the timing of contaminant exposure affects stream ecosystem productivity. In this study, we simulated a storm in all treatment streams. We then dosed streams according to their treatment with a chemical mixture mimicking the concentration and streamwater chemical composition of a highly contaminated stream in Baltimore, Maryland in a pulse at different stages of biofilm recovery (1, 7, and 14 days post-storm). We sampled biofilm growth, microbial community composition, extracellular enzyme activity, nutrient uptake, and single-rock productivity and respiration at regular intervals. We also monitored dissolved oxygen, temperature, and light using sensors to model whole-stream metabolism over the recovery interval.

 

In this study of physical and chemical disturbance on stream productivity, we found that physical disturbance resulted in heterotrophic streams, but we could not detect an effect of environmentally relevant contaminant pulses on biofilm structure or function. Instead, our data suggest that the effects of contaminant pulses on productivity among treatments were masked by a release from grazing pressure because of the loss of sensitive macroinvertebrate taxa. The effects of multiple stressors in streams on biofilm structure and function might, therefore, be mediated by indirect effects on secondary production.
